None of these statements explicitly permit an action that GDPR forbids (e.g., unlawful processing, incompatible purpose processing without legal basis, unlawful special-category processing, unlawful cross-border transfers) and none set timelines that conflict with GDPR (e.g., breach notification within 72 hours; response to data subject requests within one month). The Terms of Use also do not state anything like refusing data subject rights, denying access/erasure, or claiming no breach notification obligations. Therefore, no direct contradiction is identifiable from the provided text. Note: the Terms of Use are not a full privacy notice and omit many GDPR-required disclosures, but omissions are treated as not enough information only when there is no relevant content; here there is relevant content and no explicit conflicting claim.

The provided Netflix Terms of Use do not state whether Netflix applies/does not apply GDPR, nor do they characterize their processing as falling into any Article 2 exclusion or outside Union law. results.explanation: Article 2 is a scope provision (what processing the GDPR applies to and what it excludes). A contradiction would require the document to explicitly claim, for example, that GDPR does not apply to Netflix’s automated personal data processing, or that Netflix treats its processing as purely personal/household, or that it is law-enforcement processing by a competent authority, etc. The Terms of Use mainly cover subscription, billing, service usage restrictions, and communications. While the document references using information (e.g., device ID, payment method, contact information) for offer eligibility, it does not make any explicit claim about GDPR applicability or any Article 2 exclusion. Therefore, no direct contradiction can be established from the text provided.

results.regulation: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 7 – Conditions for consent
results.message: GDPR Article 7 concerns conditions for consent (demonstrability, clear distinguishability, right to withdraw at any time, being informed of withdrawal right, and withdrawal being as easy as giving con...
results.explanation:
GDPR Article 7 concerns conditions for consent (demonstrability, clear distinguishability, right to withdraw at any time, being informed of withdrawal right, and withdrawal being as easy as giving consent; plus assessing whether consent is freely given, including whether a contract/service is conditional on unnecessary processing).

In the provided Netflix Terms of Use excerpt, there is limited consent-related content. The document includes (1) an explicit consent choice for remote-access customer support, stating that if the user does not consent, Netflix will provide assistance through other means—this does not contradict Article 7 and supports the idea that service is not conditional on that consent. (2) a setting to “turn off test participation at any time,” which is consistent with the concept of withdrawal/opt-out being available.

The excerpt does not state anything that would directly contradict Article 7 (e.g., that consent cannot be withdrawn, that withdrawal is harder than giving consent, that consent is bundled indistinguishably into other matters, or that the service/contract is conditional on consenting to unnecessary processing). While the document also does not affirmatively describe GDPR-compliant consent recordkeeping or the full withdrawal-right notice requirements, absence of those details is not a contradiction under the task definition. Therefore, no contradiction is identified based on the provided text.

While the Terms select California law for contract governance, that is not a direct statement negating GDPR’s territorial applicability and therefore is not a contradiction of Article 3.

Because there is no explicit statement permitting avoidance of GDPR applicability or denying GDPR’s reach when targeting EU individuals, no contradiction is identified.

results.regulation: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 8 – Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services
results.message: Document text: "Minimum age. You must be at least 13 years old or the minimum age required in your country to consent to use the Services. If you are under 18 you must have your parent or legal guardi...
results.explanation: The regulation imposes an age-of-consent threshold for children’s consent in relation to information society services in the EU (default 16, with Member State option to lower to 13–15) and requires parental authorization (and reasonable verification efforts) when the child is below that threshold. The Terms explicitly allow use from age 13 and do not tie the parental-consent requirement to the GDPR Article 8 threshold (instead using under-18) and do not describe any verification of parental responsibility. This creates a contradiction because the Terms, as written, allow EU children below the Article 8 threshold (e.g., 13–15 where the threshold is 16) to use the service without explicitly requiring the specific parental authorization/verification regime mandated by Article 8.
results.contradiction_details: Document text: "Minimum age. You must be at least 13 years old or the minimum age required in your country to consent to use the Services. If you are under 18 you must have your parent or legal guardian’s permission to use the Services." Conflict: GDPR Article 8 requires that for information society services offered to children in the EU, processing based on consent is lawful only if the child is at least 16 (unless a Member State sets a lower age, but not below 13), and if below that threshold the controller must obtain/verify consent from the holder of parental responsibility and make reasonable efforts to verify it. The document sets a blanket minimum age of 13 and only requires parental permission for users under 18, which permits 13–15 year-olds to use the service without explicitly requiring parental consent/authorization for those below the applicable Article 8 age threshold (commonly 16) and without stating any reasonable-efforts verification of parental responsibility. This directly conflicts with the regulation’s consent conditions for under-threshold children.

results.regulation: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 3 – Territorial scope
results.message: Document text: "Our Services are not intended for distribution to or use in any country or territory where such distribution or use would violate local law or would subject us to any regulations in an...
results.explanation: GDPR Article 3 establishes that GDPR applies when processing is in the context of an EU establishment or when a non-EU entity offers goods/services to individuals in the EU or monitors their behavior in the EU; applicability is determined by these factual criteria, not by a provider's stated intent to avoid being subject to a jurisdiction's regulations. The document includes a clause indicating the service is not intended to be used where it would subject WhatsApp to another country/territory's regulations and reserves the right to limit service accordingly. This is in tension with (and effectively contradicts) the regulation’s principle that GDPR applicability cannot be avoided by such positioning if the factual targeting/monitoring criteria are met.
results.contradiction_details: Document text: "Our Services are not intended for distribution to or use in any country or territory where such distribution or use would violate local law or would subject us to any regulations in another country or territory." This suggests WhatsApp intends to avoid being subject to other jurisdictions' regulations (including EU GDPR) by limiting distribution/use, which conflicts with GDPR Article 3's rule that GDPR applies based on EU establishment or targeting/monitoring individuals in the EU and cannot be avoided by structuring operations or processing location to escape applicability.

We reserve the right to limit our Services in any country or territory.”

results.regulation: General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679, Article 5: Principles relating to processing of personal data
results.message: Document text: "We do not warrant that any information provided by us is accurate, complete, or useful". GDPR Article 5(1)(d) requires personal data to be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to dat...
results.explanation: The document contains a broad accuracy disclaimer. GDPR Article 5 imposes an affirmative obligation on controllers to ensure accuracy of personal data and to rectify/erase inaccurate data without delay. While the disclaimer is framed as a warranty limitation (and not an explicit statement that WhatsApp will process inaccurate personal data), it directly asserts non-assurance of accuracy for information provided by WhatsApp, which is inconsistent with the GDPR’s accuracy principle when applied to personal data processing. Other GDPR Article 5 principles (purpose limitation, minimisation, storage limitation, accountability) are not directly contradicted in the provided text, but this explicit non-accuracy warranty statement conflicts with the accuracy obligation.
results.contradiction_details: Document text: "We do not warrant that any information provided by us is accurate, complete, or useful". GDPR Article 5(1)(d) requires personal data to be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date, with inaccurate data erased or rectified without delay. A blanket disclaimer that WhatsApp does not warrant accuracy conflicts with the regulatory requirement to ensure accuracy of personal data processed (at least for the personal data WhatsApp controls/uses).

Because the document does not make explicit claims that contradict Article 7 (e.g., “you cannot withdraw consent” or “withdrawal is harder than giving consent”), but also does not provide the necessary consent-management details, the correct classification is insufficient information rather than compliant or non-compliant.

results.regulation: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (General Data Protection Regulation), Article 8 – Conditions applicable to child's consent in relation to information society services
results.message: GDPR Article 8 requires that, for information society services offered directly to a child in the EU, consent is valid if the child is at least 16 (unless a Member State sets a lower age, not below 13...
results.explanation:
GDPR Article 8 requires that, for information society services offered directly to a child in the EU, consent is valid if the child is at least 16 (unless a Member State sets a lower age, not below 13), and if below the applicable age threshold, consent must be given/authorized by the holder of parental responsibility, with reasonable efforts to verify.

The document contains an EU/EEA-specific age rule: users in the “European Region” must be at least 16 to use the service (or higher if required locally) without parental approval, and it states that if the user is not old enough to have authority to agree to the Terms, a parent/guardian must agree on their behalf. This does not contradict GDPR Article 8’s age-threshold framework; it is at least as strict as the default GDPR threshold (16) and contemplates parental involvement for those lacking authority.

The document does not explicitly describe ‘reasonable efforts’ to verify parental responsibility/consent, but absence of that detail is not a contradiction; it is simply not addressed. Therefore, no direct conflict is present, and the text is consistent with the regulation’s age/parental-consent structure.
results.evidence: “Age. If you live in a country or territory in the European Region, you must be at least 16 years old to use our Services or such greater age required in your country or territory to register for or use our Services without parental approval. ... In addition to being of the minimum required age to use our Services under applicable law, if you are not old enough to have authority to agree to our Terms in your country or territory, your parent or guardian must agree to our Terms on your behalf in order for you to use the Services.”
